document.docAuthor: Rafał Gosik, Peter Sprick, Jiří Skuhrovec, Magdalena Deruś & Martin Hommes
document.masterDocTitle: Morphology and identification of the mature larvae of several species of the genus Otiorhynchus (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Entiminae) from Central Europe with an update of the life history traits

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Morphology and identification of the mature larvae of several species of the genus Otiorhynchus (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Entiminae) from Central Europe with an update of the life history traits

heading.emphasis:
Otiorhynchus
(s. str.)
tenebricosus (Herbst, 1784 )
complex:
Otiorhynchus fuscipes (Olivier, 1807 )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined:
4 larvae
(
Fig. 214
). Ith Mountains, southwest of Hannover, in the district of Hameln, Niedersachsen, 350–400 m ,
13.10 .2011
, 2 ex.; dto., 0 1.09 .2012, 1 ex.; dto.,
26.03 .2012
, 1 ex.

Remarks about sampling and development. All larvae were received from field-sampling in a beech forest on limestone, at about 350–400 m above sea level in the submontane climate zone. The larvae were found between the roots of young
Fraxinus excelsior
L. plants, growing intermixed with
Allium ursinum
L., which can be recognized by their characteristic subterranean overwintering organs, the longitudinal bulbs. As we know there are no data on the life-cycle of this taxon including larval development.
Coloration. Head dark brown; all thoracic and abdominal segments from dark yellow to brownish; cuticle almost smooth.

Differential diagnosis . See “Key to larvae of selected
Otiorhynchus
species” and Tables 1 , 2 .
